Authored by [LIBER](https://libereurope.eu/) professionals, these guides offer short introductions to applying digital scholarship and data science in modern library work. Each guide includes the authors' personal recommendations for tutorials, further reading, and communities of practice to support your learning journey.

::: {.grid}
::: {.g-col-4}
<div class="card text-white bg-primary mb-3" style="max-width: 20rem;">
  <div class="card-header">**Where to begin?**</div>
<div class="card-body">Our [Getting Started in DS](gettingstarted.qmd) guide provides a helpful starting point for understanding digital scholarship and data science in the context of research libraries! </div>
</div>

<div class="card text-white bg-secondary mb-3" style="max-width: 20rem;">
  <div class="card-header">**Group Study**</div>
  <div class="card-body">The materials recommended here can be used to start up a reading group, or hold a hands-on workshop! See our _DS Topic Guide_ on how to [Start your own training programme](dstp.qmd). It has tons of tips and tricks from British Library Digital Research Team colleagues on using these guides support group learning opportunities at your own library or network.</div>
</div>
:::

::: {.g-col-8}
<div class="card text-white bg-success mb-3">
  <div class="card-header">**Self-study & Quick Reference**</div>
  <div class="card-body">The guides aim to be a useful first point of entry into complex topics in digital scholarship and data science and their application in the library world. They are not meant to be read in any particular order and learners are invited to jump in and out of individual guides as personal curiosity or practical need dictates. 

Each _DS Topic Guide_ is designed to make it easy to quickly find the information you might need: 

- Introduction to the topic
- Relevance to the library sector (case studies/use cases)
- Hands-on activities and other self-guided tutorial(s)
- Recommended reading & viewing
- Finding Communities of Practice</div>
</div>
